sentence.text: ﻿Patient 3 was a male fetus from the third pregnancy of a nonconsanguineous healthy Caucasian couple.
US examination at GA 18 + 5 showed short limbs, bowed femora, absent vertebral ossification, a narrow thorax (thoracic circumference: 5th centile for GA), and short ribs (Fig. 1B–D).
However, the facial appearance was unremarkable, the calvaria were normally ossified, and the trunk was normal in length.
The couple was counseled with regard to a severe, possibly lethal skeletal dysplasia, and they decided to terminate the pregnancy at GA 20 + 3.
The postnatal examination confirmed the prenatal US findings (Fig. 2D,E).
The lungs were small, but not hypoplastic (lung/body weight ratio 0.024, normal value >0.015).
Histological examination of the growth plates from ribs, clavicles and femur showed hypercellularity of resting cartilage and absence of proliferative and hypertrophic zones.
Cytoplasmic inclusion bodies were not found (not shown).
Skeletal radiographs confirmed absent ossification of the vertebral bodies and sacrum.
Ossification of the neural arches was present in the cervical, upper, and middle thoracic spine.
The skull appeared normal in ossification.
Only 11 pairs of ossified ribs were present.
The ribs were short but finely modeled without a beaded appearance.
The ilia were small and crescent shaped.
The pubic and ischial rami were not ossified.
The tubular bones were short and bowed with flared, cupped metaphyses and longitudinally oriented large metaphyseal spurs (Fig. 3C).
The short tubular bones were relatively well ossified.
